numbered_ace_sentences: 1. I notice differences in the percentages in the graph.
2. The graph shows how often young people reach out to their parents.
3. The graph distinguishes at least once a day and a few times a week.
4. Young people use methods to reach out to their parents.
5. Men use some preferred methods to reach out to their parents.
6. Women use some preferred methods to reach out to their parents.
7. The graph shows variation across gender.
8. Young women are more likely than young men to reach out to their parents.
9. This is true across all three methods.
10. The increase for women is similar for sending texts and for phone or video-chat.
11. The increase for women is not as strong for visiting in person.
12. Men are less likely than women to reach out to their parents.
13. This is true for all three methods.
14. The reason for this difference is unknown.
15. Some young men took the online survey.
16. These young men are aged 18 to 34.
17. About 2 in 4 of these young men reach out to their parents at least once a day or a few times a week.
18. Some young women took the online survey.
19. These young women are aged 18 to 34.
20. About 3 in 4 of these young women reach out to their parents at least once a day or a few times a week.
21. The parents of women tend to be more involved in the lives of these women.
22. This is because these women reach out more.
23. I am a young man.
24. I do not reach out to my parents very often.
25. This relates to men in my community.
26. This relates to the male community as a whole.
27. This could correlate with a silent epidemic among men.
28. Some men are afraid to reach out.
29. Some men prefer to keep to themselves.
30. The headline is: Gender Differences in Parental Communication: Involvement in Their Children's Young Adult Lives.
